results.title: Temperature
results.creator_credit: Ivo Burum, Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
Temperature influences a plant’s growth, and plants have developed strategies to cope with extremes in temperature. In commercial plant production, statistical techniques are used to determine mean temperatures for different areas. Combining temperature and time, gives the concept of ‘heat summation’ measured in ‘degree days’. Crop Modelling uses a computer to combine data on light intensity, temperature and the rate of photosynthesis to determine optimum growing conditions.

results.title: Temperate rain forest
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, John Taylor, George Johnson and Don White
results.brief_description: One of a group of short films on various climatic, geographic and ecological zones in British Columbia, The Temperate Rain Forest examines the special characteristics, including the life cycle and food chain, of the northwest coastal rain forest. Its highly acidic soil results in a specialized plant community and an abundance of amphibians and reptiles. As the camera reveals, it is a place of exquisite beauty, and one that has an important place in the ecology.

results.title: Temperament unsuited
results.brief_description: The narrative explores the predicament faced by an unconventional student teacher attempting to orient himself to the conservative world of secondary school teaching. Cast includes Steve J. Spears, Robyn Nevin, Deborah Kennedy, Ken Goodlet, Peter Carroll, Jude Kuring, Paul Mason, Jenny McNae, Max Phipps, Phil Ross.

results.title: Telling the World
results.brief_description: As the title suggests, ‘Telling The World’ was made for an overseas audience as was much of the Government film unit’s output. It covers the roles and functions of the Cinema and Photographic Branch and shows Bert Ive filming some of the iconic images he would capture of important Australian events and places. The opening sequence shows a meeting between the Cinema Branch’s Officer-in-Charge Lyn Maplestone and Bert Ive, who appear periodically throughout the film. Ive continued to work for the branch until his death in 1939. The film has been sepia toned, a specialised chemical treatment enhancing black and white film with a warmer tone. Some scenes in the processing laboratory are tinted red. An excellent example of the period’s documentary and innovative filmmaking techniques. Source: NFSA Film Australia Collection.

results.title: Telling tales
results.brief_description:
Telling Tales are real stories told and produced by people with a disability and those who are disadvantaged.

Telling Tales challenges the ‘norms’ as often represented by mainstream film with first person accounts that provide a real opportunity to be seen and heard. The stories explore personal journeys of identity, displacement, relationships, longing and memory.

Telling Tales was produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for Telling Tales.

results.title: Telling a story in pictures
results.brief_description: An amateur film designed to demonstrate basic camera technique. The first half of the film, Version 1, is shot entirely in one and the same longshot. A little girl takes a parcel up to the door of a house, leaves it on the porch, runs back to the gate, hides behind it, and watches the lady of the house open the door, pick up the parcel, shake her head and walk in again. The second half, Version 2, is precisely the same story told with the judicious use of medium shots and close-ups. Thus we see the message in the box - `April Fool’ - and the reactions of both the little girl and the lady.

results.title: Tell my wife I won't be home for dinner
results.creator_credit: Paul Ferguson, Cygnet Guild Communications and Jack Duncan
results.brief_description: Three case studies demonstrate a variety of examples of common mismanagement of time and their consequences. This film offers guidance on how to recognise ineffective time management and to establish effective time use rules.
